last_all_stats_history

private AllStatsHistory last_all_stats_history
This member saves the last statistics object to check it with the next one so that we dont put repeats in the histories list. But if by chance the stats look the same in the future, then that will be ok, which is why we do it on the get side, not the set side.

This is our homegrown loggin system, because system outs dont come thru the JUnit and Ant setup. Should look into that...not tonight!

Method Detail

getWhateverHash

public java.util.Hashtable getWhateverHash(java.lang.String elements,
                                           java.lang.String names,
                                           java.lang.String values)

This method retrieves a list of option style elements from an xml file with the following format:

elements ("word")

names content /names("text")

values content /values("definition")

/elements

THen is creates a Hash like this keys=names hash(key)=value.

getOptionsHash

public java.util.Hashtable getOptionsHash()
This method reads a xml file with the format: option name=xxx value=xxx and returns these in a hastable.

public java.util.Hashtable getWhateverKeyValHash(java.lang.String option,
                                                 java.lang.String _name,
                                                 java.lang.String _value)
This method takes an element name, two sub-elements names from which it constructs the key-value pairs stored in a hashtable.

getWords

public java.util.Vector getWords()
This methods retrieve the following from a Word object private String text; private String definition; private int writing_level; private int reading_level; date_of_entry test []

We had a problem when there was no reading or writing level present for some words, hence the two separate try blocks. This is a workaround, as the system should add these attributes, or make sure they are there in some other way.

getRetiredElement

private boolean getRetiredElement(org.jdom.Element e)
This method is used in the getWordsForTest() method. There may or may not be a retired element so a null pointer error means retired = flase;

I remeber reading that using errors as a design feature was not a good idea. So should we add retired elements to every single word file when for a long time a word wont need it? Not sure about the performance trade offs when this class is bloated and horrible to begin with...

getFilteredWords

public java.util.Vector getFilteredWords(WordFilter word_filter)
This method, like its brother, gets the following from a Word object filtered/screened according to properties set in the WordFilter object passed in.

IF any of the Word properties are null, then that property is set with a string saying null instead of risking a null object, or 0 if it is an int.

If filter properties are null, then it is assumed to be a default non-filtered property..

filterWord

private boolean filterWord(Word word,
                           WordFilter word_filter,
                           int index)
The actual filtering of word objects happens here.

Here are some of the properties we set in the WordFilter object.

word_filter.setStartIndex(0);

word_filter.setMinMaxRange("0-0");

word_filter.setType("reading");

word_filter.setCategory("october.xml");

If properties have not been set in the filter object, then they are skipped by using a try/catch block.

private Word checkForNull(org.jdom.Element e)

addHistory

public void addHistory(AllStatsHistory all_stats_history)

We create a history element (in the most redundant way possbile) based on this xml schema:

Thu Oct 13 19:10:24 KST 2005

182

49.7

913

1.2

0.81

317

474

99

22

201

485

137

57 added: long session_start; long session_end; int number_of_session_tests;

This old version deosnt contain the last 24 hour period session information.

replaceWord

public void replaceWord(java.lang.String original_text,
                        java.lang.String new_text,
                        java.lang.String new_def)

Replace word method replaces both word and definition properties.

Formerly we encoded the text and definitions here, but after commenting them out, it seemed to have no effect. Here is the code we used after the if (text.equals(original_text)) block: //String enc_name = encoder.encodeThis( name); //String enc_value = encoder.encodeThis(value);

replaceWordAndChangeTest

public void replaceWordAndChangeTest(WordTestMemory wtm,
                                     WordTestResult wtr)

Replace word method replaces both word and definition properties, and changes the reading/writing level either up or down.

Just in case there are two different test with the same date and time (What are the chances of that, really? if the clock stops...?) we should really make sure the test name and not only the date match.

We have to enclose the test element checks in a try/catch block because the word may have no tests yet.

This method is not used right now, as we replace the word info and change the level in different methods, so that the user can choose to change the level, but not replace the text-definition, and vice versa.

changeWordLevel

public java.lang.String changeWordLevel(WordTestMemory wtm,
                                        WordTestResult wtr,
                                        java.lang.String max_level)

This method changes the reading/writing level either up or down.

The word test result must be changed from fail to pass to increment, and the opposite for decrements.

replaceWordLevel

private void replaceWordLevel(org.jdom.Element word,
                              java.lang.String level,
                              java.lang.String type)

getAdjustLevel

private java.lang.String getAdjustLevel(org.jdom.Element word,
                                        java.lang.String type,
                                        java.lang.String grade,
                                        java.lang.String test_level,
                                        java.lang.String max_level,
                                        java.lang.String original_level)
This is the third iteration of this method. We get the test_level from the test type (or category), then increment or decrement based on the test result.

If the test is at level 0, it should only be incremented once.

If the test is 1 or higher, it gets incremented twice, once to bring it back to its pre-test level, and another to simulate a passed test.

adjustLevel

private void adjustLevel(org.jdom.Element word,
                         java.lang.String type,
                         java.lang.String grade)

This method increments or decrements (using grade) the reading or writing level (using type) of a word element.

The level is incremented or decremented twice because if the user failed a test for a word at level 1, then the word is now at level 0, so to reverse the test we need to increment it up 2 to level 2. However, if the original level is only 0, then we only want to add 1, because words arnt allowed to go below 0.

If the original level was 0 or 1, then the current level would be the same: 0.

getAdjustLevel

private java.lang.String getAdjustLevel(org.jdom.Element word,
                                        java.lang.String type,
                                        java.lang.String grade)
Copy of previous method except it returns the new level value

changeScore

public void changeScore(java.lang.String date,
                        java.lang.String new_score)
Here we look in a test file to match the test date and then replace it with the new test score.

Were looking to change an element like this one:

70 Mon Nov 01 22:26:22 PST 2004

Note the responisibilty for creating the new test score happens in the Struts Action class ChangeUpdateAction, where it knows how many words are in the test, and what the pass/fail of all the other words is.

addWord

public void addWord(Word word_obj)
We need to create word object to add to the file passed in at creation time.

The reading and writing levels are fixed at 0, but it would be easy to let the user dictate other leves, as well as other elements.

editWord

public void editWord(Word old_word_obj,
                     Word new_word_obj)

Change a word object.

This has been a persitently annoying error. When we first made this method over a year ago, if didnt work. Because content management is not the purpose of this package, we let is slide. But being able to edit words when it is most needed, such as after a test seems too necessary to avoid.

So we took another look and got the test in the FileStorageTest working.

However, the JDOMSolution test continued to fail.

Thats why the second method was created, to experiment with recording the document within the edit method.

recordWordScore

public java.lang.String recordWordScore(java.lang.String word,
                                        java.lang.String grade,
                                        java.lang.String test_file,
                                        java.lang.String date,
                                        java.lang.String type,
                                        java.lang.String max_level,
                                        java.lang.String org_level)

(Note, This method came from the original CreateJDOMList in the com.businessglue.util. package.)

Here we create a new "test" element with grade/file/date sub-elements.

We also update each individual word level dependant on type.

Note: We cyclce thru the word list again here. It would be nice to merge this with the other previous cycle when the words are graded. Maybe this is not possible because what we use is a hashmap, no a reference to the xml file. Maybe we could bind an XPath reference to the key, or use and array...?

public java.lang.String recordWordScoreSearchById(long word_id,

Create a new "test" element with grade/file/date sub-elements.

We also update each individual word level dependant on type.

Note: We cycle thru the word list again here. It would be nice to merge this with the other previous cycles when the words are graded. Maybe this is not possible because what we use is a hashmap, no a reference to the xml file. Maybe we could bind an XPath reference to the key, or use and array...?

addIds

public int addIds()

updateWordLevel

private java.lang.String updateWordLevel(org.jdom.Element word,
                                         java.lang.String pass_fail,
                                         java.lang.String word_text,
                                         java.lang.String date,
                                         java.lang.String type,
                                         java.lang.String max_level,
                                         java.lang.String org_level)

(Note, This method also comes from the original CreateJDOMList in the com.businessglue.util. package.)

This method changes the 'level' element in the words file and adds the result to the word_levels Hashmap for later retrieval.

Without the updateWordLevel method, we had the levels updated an arbitrary amount of times per test, when only once was desired. It's because the test results come in as a Hastable, and we cycle trhu that hashtable looking for those words in the xml file. So for each word, we have to cycle again thru the xml file looking for that word.

There must be a better way of doing this, so the updateWordLevel method is a workaround to get things started with correct behaviour.

wordIsAlreadyUpdated

private boolean wordIsAlreadyUpdated(java.lang.String word_text)

(Note, This method also comes from the original CreateJDOMList in the com.businessglue.util. package.)

Because we had the same words being updated numerous times, this method uses a Hashset whith the method.contains(word) to exclude further updates.

THis method should be considerd a workaround, as there is definately a better way.
